fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.bodyText: • An editorial (Taking Shakespeare from page to stage is an art in itself, 31 October, page 22) expressed the idea that there are two battlegrounds in modern theatre – how to treat classic works, and whether directors should be regarded as artists or handmaidens to the text – but omitted to attribute it to the theatre director Robert Icke. • The constituency in which Zac Goldsmith’s resignation has triggered a byelection is Richmond Park, not Richmond. It shouldn’t be confused with the Richmond constituency in Yorkshire (Division haunts the left. This is our chance to lay it to rest, 31 October, page 23). • A fashion column (Which US president best rocked the White House look?, 1 November, page 15, G2) said that Harry S Truman had a very fine game in bow ties while his cousin Teddy knew how to rock a waistcoat and pocketwatch. It was Franklin D Roosevelt who was a fan of the bow tie and related to Theodore Roosevelt.
